body: @dudgnskim I see that the `--host` argument of your `mlflow server` invocation is `x.x.x.x`, which you defined as the IP address of Node B. Can you replace the argument `--host=x.x.x.x` with `--host=0.0.0.0` and try again?
@dbczumar Tried with 0.0.0.0 and the same issue still occurs. Could you explain what the meaning of using 0.0.0.0 as the host ip in this case?
@dbczumar Actually, instead of 504 != 200, this time it says 503 != 200. The rest of the error message is the same.

@dudgnskim `0.0.0.0` indicates that the server should bind to all network interfaces, in order to listen for external traffic. If possible, can you try using the [GNU netcat](http://netcat.sourceforge.net) tool on Node A to determine if port 5000 is accessible on Node B? You can run `nc -vz x.x.x.x 5000`.

It says:
Node A:~# nc -vz x.x.x.x 5000
Connection to x.x.x.x 5000 port [tcp/*] succeeded!
from Node A

@dbczumar It says:
Node A:~# nc -vz x.x.x.x 5000
Connection to x.x.x.x 5000 port [tcp/*] succeeded!
from Node A

** Just in case you haven't received any notification from my previous comment
@dudgnskim Sorry I missed this! Are there any logs produced on the server side (Node B)? Have you tried using version `0.7.0` of MLflow on both Nodes?
@dbczumar I just upgraded and tried again, but it seems like the problem persists..

@dudgnskim Is there any log output from the tracking server running on Node B?

Also, are `/file/store/location` and `/default/artifact/root` valid paths on Node B?
@dbczumar Could you tell me where to look for the log file?
@dudgnskim Log output should be emitted in the shell that you used to execute the `mlflow server...` command
